job_title: Provider Enrollment Specialist in Wethersfield, CT
pros: The compensation is excellent, and the CVO provides a hybrid schedule, allowing for a good work-life balance. Additionally, the longer you stay with the company, the more paid time off you accumulate. The staff members are highly knowledgeable and collaborate effectively as a team.
cons: One drawback is that the management lacks knowledge about the work being performed at the CVO, resulting in drastic changes that have created an extremely toxic environment. They not only fail to practice the behaviors they expect employees to follow but also treat them as second-class citizens. It has become common practice to belittle, harass, and accuse numerous staff members of utilizing their FMLA benefits, denying their right to reasonable accommodations recommended by their physicians. Surprisingly, there hasn't been a lawsuit against the company and/or the Director and Manager, considering the circumstances.

pros: Not too many pros for this company.
cons: The pay and vacation is horrible.  Very hard to get time off.  Unless you are dying.  They pay lower than most hospitals in the country.  Over work and under paid.  Work load is ridiculous. They want  more work for less pay.  When a department is short staff they'd rather work their current employees like slaves. Oftentimes employees have 6-10 day work schedules with a one day off in between.  Issues between co-workers gets ignored. There is a culture of work place bullying, and slackers that they let get away with murder only because they are lazy to hire better individuals.  They tolerate a lot of bull from those they value.   For example: Favorites can come in late, have long breaks, bully co workers and bend rules. They bend the policies for their favorite employees.  Don't waste your time complaining about a bullying co worker because it goes in one ear and right out the next. The manager on site seems to be a coward in dealing with veteran employees.  Some employees are lazy as heck leaving those who really work to take the brunt of tasks.  No support at all.

review_title: Just a number, not a valued employee
pros: Hartford Healthcare has great affiliated hospitals that promote positive work environments and strive to keep respect, caring and teamwork at the forefront of daily operations. In smaller departments you'll find leadership to be authentic and humanistic. You can make a wonderful career here. Colleagues are genuinely nice which makes the day fun and easy when you have a good support system around you.
cons: If you work for the mother-ship (HH) directly, you are treated as more of a number than a valued employee. Given the financial state of Hartford Hospital, layoffs are abundant every few months. Here today, gone tomorrow is many a department employee. Thus, leaving a wake of overburdened staff to do the work of 2, 3, 4 or 5+ lost team members. This also puts added stress on leadership to either "manage up or, manage out" (legit philosophy around HH) when staff is less than stellar because of added stress, workloads and sometimes unreasonable deadlines. Rumor mill believes the CEO is running the business into the ground or straight into bankruptcy.

review_title: The second worst job I have ever held
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Norwich, CT
pros: Some of the employees throughout the hospital made work tolerable most days, interacting with patients also had its ups. Otherwise, I dreaded clocking in for every shift I worked from a few days after starting.
cons: Employees feed into a very negative workplace culture, and everyone is oblivious as to how to fix it. Work place bullying is excused and ultimately allowed, management is extremely hands-off, and employees beneath management run the show, for better or for worse. I did not find it to be a supportive environment either. Any questions were met with comments and attitudes that belittled the asker. Circling back to hands-off management, there is also minimal support for off shifts... Second and especially third shift were SOL if there were any issues with anything about their shifts. As mentioned by others, favoritism is also very popular at Backus. I found many employees, management and not, to be extremely unprofessional and even childish  in some individuals.

job_title: Case Manager, Registered Nurse in Englewood, NJ

cons: Pay is lower than other agencies, benefits have very high deductible and poor coverage , tuition offered as a package attraction is only authorized if manager accept it( based if he/she likes you), client and satisfaction geared. Very little communication and poor management. Only worried about budget and surveys. Low pay for mileage. wear and tear of car, nurses are given work as factory workers not professionals. Never know what else they will add to your workday without consulting you. Be ready to get paid for 8 hours and be expected to work 24 hours a day! Management will lie and make up things about you if they want to let you go, document everything! There is no diversity in the management latter.

pros: My direct supervisor was a true mentor--helped me immensely to grow in my field.  The benefits were quite good.  Most of all, the majority of the clinicians were skilled and dedicated

There were Office Space-like meetings to indoctrinate staff in the new corporate philosophies--"the Seven Pillars of Excellence" or some such nonsense.  There was a constant mantra that feedback was welcome, yet departmental meetings were chaperoned by administrative lackeys.  What staff needed was more time with patients and tools to make documentation and communication easier--instead, we got key chains with the logo "you are the key to Hartford Hospital's success!"

review_title: Too many employees changing positions and promoting the wrong people to management.

They need to make arangments with the town or state to keep the hill to the hospital clear in the snow because ambulances have gotten stuck trying to get a patients to the hospital. They need this done asap before someone dies.

pros:

Old technology

Was given less thn 12 weeks to prove myself not even six months.
Having 8 years of experience in IT field in the end of 10th week manager says you should go for entry level position. My skills and confidence was questioned.
Very rude, unethical and old environment.  Employees have been in this role for over 25 years and don't even know what lync is. 
All my initial weeks was wasted in meeting people all over which was called orientation but was waste of time in my field. Orientation should be for one day not for weeks. Then they expect I prove myself after wasting weeks and during end of the year when people are out on vacation.
Anyway I am happy I am out. After spending couple of weeks there I realized they had the oldest systems and I would have missed out the newest technology if I continued.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Hartford, CT

Low employee moral.  Currently, management allows overtime because the company is extremely understaffed.  There is no employee training for career advancement.  High turn over rate. Employees that are poor performance employees are not written up or let go.  Management only cares that there is someone in at the front desk regardless if they employee does their job or not.

review_title: VNA Home Heathcare is a great place to work!

It was a great place to work with the best nurses, physical therapists, occupational therapists, social workers, and home health aides in the area.  The pay was good and the opportunity for educational and skill growth was excellent.  Yes, it was hard work, but being paid hourly made it worthwhile to commit to.  I met many wonderful patients (and some not so wonderful ones) and felt very supported by our organization to do the very best for the patient that could be done.  I only resigned because I moved away from the area.
cons: The worst part of working at VNA was the weather.  We had to work no matter what the weather was.  It snowed a lot some winters and that made travel slow and treacherous.

review_title: Hostile Work Evnironment - Bottom Line Value

Good employees are not valued or promoted so they leave... constantly training new people. Very poor interview process looking at the employees who are hired. Employees live in fear of programs closing or violent clients. Since there is so much emphasis on the bottom line adolescents are often accepted when they do not meet what the program dictates. The employees are not trained to handle the clients that are accepted. Over and over again staff would go to upper management about concerns and they would be belittled and told that nothing was wrong.

pros: Awesome teammates, maybe one good senior manager.
cons:
A lot to list, lets see if I am able to put them all down!
1)  Horrible PTO system.  You gain about 7.35 hours of PTO per pay period which is not even enough for a full day off and apparently they "increased it" to an amount that "covers you" for the Holiday's and such when the office is closed.  I started in October and did not have enough PTO for the holiday's and this ended up counting against me.
2)  Our department spent more time updating our Standard of Work book than actually working.  Our Standard Work would literally change twice a week at minimum and more and more work was being dumped on us at the same time.
3)  The supervisor and manager were terrible micro-managers.
4)  If you are (un)lucky enough to get on a Performance Improvement Plan, good luck to you, because they do not help you out at all.  They will monitor your work with a fine tooth comb and your managers will be the first to bring up how you are still failing, all without TRYING to help make work better.
5)  HHC have these Leadership Behaviors that they make you "live by" but they do not even do it themselves.  From personal experience, if you have a "Courageous Conversation" be prepared to pay the consequences! Once you speak up they will do all they can to make your life hell and try to force you out.
6)  Management does not listen to their employees at all.  Morale is awful in multiple departments and nothing was being done.  Instead, more and more people were quitting and leaving for better employers.
7)  One of the most frustrating part about HHC is that our Department Director even stated that "if you are unhappy in your role, just come talk to me and we will find a better fit."  This was all just a game they were playing to make it sound like they really did care but they don't.  Look back up to # 5.  If you speak up they will find a way to get rid of you as fast as they can.


All in all I had a very unpleasant experience.  For such a huge organization it really felt like all they want is money, money, money and the employees are the ones that get screwed.  Do yourself a favor and stay away from Hartford Healthcare.  Look at Yale New Haven Health or even Middlesex Health for better options!  Think about your mental health and put yourself first because this place definitely will not.

review_title: Human Resources Should Be About People, Not Numbers
pros: Coworkers were great, flexible schedule, close parking, fair pay, decent benefits/ 401k, Large corporation, simple interviewing process, opportunity for young people
cons:
I worked in HR, specifically in retirement. Management was more concerned about how fast you answered a phone than how you actually dealt with retirees and current employees retirement questions/ cases. It didn't matter to them how in depth a persons issue or case was, all they cared about was how fast cases were closed, phone answering speeds, and their ratings. Because employees were forced to care more about speed, small details were continually missed and extra stress was put on most people working there. Instead of taking the time to do things correctly, the departments of life cycle, retirement, and benefits were constantly doing clean up projects, onto of their own department work, for upper managements mistakes and carelessness. The office setting was miserable because of the understaffing, constant unrealistic goals set, and unwillingness to change the way cases were approached. In my time there, there was constant turnover of employees. Instead of replacing these employees they would hire temps with little to no experience in HR and expect them to be seasoned Vets within days. When I was hired it took two weeks to gain access to the computer systems. I saw this happen for a few other temps hired in my 8 months there. Lastly, they promise their temps that the jobs are temp-to-hire. I was told positions would be available in 2-3 months from my hire. I would check bi-weekly with my boss on possible openings until I was told by email that the budget wouldn't allow for any unless someone left. That is not okay to lie to employees during the interview process and is why two other employees left around the same time I did. There is no honesty from management and the separation it creates from their workers is truly what made this place unbearable to work at. 

One last Example: my head boss did not know how to use our main system (peoplesoft) and seemed to have no desire to even try to learn it
